Question Text: Which of the following terms describe Ethernet addresses that can send one frame and is delivered to multiple devices on the LAN? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Broadcast address
b. Multicast address
c. IP address
d. MAC address
e. Unicast address
LLM Explanation: Broadcast and multicast addresses are used to send Ethernet frames to multiple devices on a LAN. A broadcast address (FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF) sends the frame to all devices, while a multicast address sends the frame to a specific group of devices that have subscribed to that multicast group. IP addresses operate at Layer 3 and are not used for Layer 2 Ethernet addressing. MAC addresses and unicast addresses refer to a single device on the LAN.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: ___________ is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision.
Choices:
a. CSMA/CD
b. CSMA/CA
c. TCP/IP
d. TCP/UDP
LLM Explanation: CSMA/CD, which stands for Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection, is a set of rules that determines how network devices respond when two devices send data at the same time on the same network segment, resulting in a collision. When a collision occurs, the devices stop transmitting, wait for a random time interval, and then retry the transmission. This helps to minimize collisions and ensures efficient use of the network medium.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 3: Fundamentals of LANs)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/ethernet/5234-csma-cd.html']

Question Text: Ethernet standard ___________ BASE-T defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling.
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet standard that defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling is 1000BASE-T. The '1000' in 1000BASE-T represents the data rate of 1000 Mbps, which is equivalent to 1 Gbps (Gigabit per second). This standard allows for Gigabit Ethernet transmission over Category 5e or better twisted-pair cabling.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'IEEE 802.3ab-1999 standard: 1000BASE-T', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gigabit_Ethernet']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Preamble field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet frame allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks. It consists of a 56-bit pattern of alternating 1s and 0s that enables bit synchronization. The preamble is followed by the Start Frame Delimiter (SFD) field.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet_frame#Preamble_and_start_frame_delimiter']

Question Text: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the ____________ IP address is in a different subnet than the host.
Choices:
a. Source
b. Destination
c. Unicast
d. Broadcast
LLM Explanation: A host sends packets to its default gateway if the destination IP address is in a different subnet than the host. The default gateway is the router interface that connects the host's local subnet to other networks. When a host needs to communicate with a device on a different subnet, it forwards the packets to the default gateway, which then routes the packets to the appropriate destination network.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 16: IP Routing', 'Cisco Networking Academy: Introduction to Networks v7.0, Module 11: IP Addressing']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Application TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol in the TCP/IP model. It is used for sending and receiving email messages between servers. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and IP (Internet Protocol) reside in the transport and network layers, respectively. Ethernet is a protocol used in the data link layer for local area networking.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition). Pearson.', 'Odom, W. (2020). CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1. Cisco Press.', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13769-5.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Transport TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) resides in the Transport layer of the TCP/IP architecture. It provides reliable, connection-oriented data delivery between applications. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an Application layer protocol, Ethernet is a Data Link layer protocol, and IP (Internet Protocol) is a Network layer protocol in the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by Kevin R. Fall, W. Richard Stevens']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: The Internet Protocol (IP) resides in the Internet layer of the TCP/IP architecture. IP is responsible for addressing, routing, and delivering packets across network boundaries. SMTP is an application layer protocol, TCP is a transport layer protocol, and Ethernet is a data link layer protocol in the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['Kurose, J. F., & Ross, K. W. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th ed.). Pearson.', 'Odom, W. (2020). CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1. Cisco Press.', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13769-5.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Data Link & Physical TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: Ethernet resides in the Data Link and Physical layers of the TCP/IP architecture. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) and TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) operate at the Application and Transport layers respectively, while IP (Internet Protocol) functions at the Network layer.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 3: Fundamentals of LANs)', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by Kevin R. Fall, W. Richard Stevens (Chapter 1: Introduction)']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols is used from PC1 to learn information from some other device on the same network?
Choices:
a. ping
b. ARP
c. DHCP
d. DNS
LLM Explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) is used by a device to learn the MAC address associated with an IP address on the same network. When a device needs to communicate with another device on the local network, it broadcasts an ARP request to resolve the IP address to the corresponding MAC address. The device with the matching IP address responds with its MAC address, allowing communication to proceed.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/dynamic-address-allocation-resolution/13718-5.html']

Question Text: If the devices below were connected with UTP Ethernet cables, which pairs of devices would require a straight-through cable? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Router and PC
b. Switch and PC
c. Hub and switch
d. Router and hub
LLM Explanation: A straight-through Ethernet cable is used when connecting devices of different types, such as a host to a switch or a router to a PC. Choices 'a' (Router and PC) and 'b' (Switch and PC) represent connections between different device types, so they would require a straight-through cable. Choices 'c' (Hub and switch) and 'd' (Router and hub) are connections between similar devices, which typically use a crossover cable instead.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/catalyst-6500-series-switches/21223-cable-connection-21223.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols are examples of TCP/IP data-link layer protocols? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. TCP
b. HTTP
c. Ethernet
d. PPP
e. SMTP
f. HTTPS
LLM Explanation: Ethernet and PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) are both examples of data-link layer protocols in the TCP/IP model. The data-link layer is responsible for node-to-node delivery of data frames on the same LAN. It provides error-free transfer of data frames from one node to another over the physical layer. TCP, HTTP, SMTP, and HTTPS are higher-layer protocols that operate at the transport layer (TCP) and application layer (HTTP, SMTP, HTTPS) of the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Cisco Press', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols, W. Richard Stevens, Addison-Wesley']

Question Text: Which of the following statements are functions of a routing protocol? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Learning routes and putting those routes into the routing table for routes advertised to the router by its neighboring routers
b. Advertising known routes to neighboring routers
c. Learning routes for subnets directly connected to the router
d. Forwarding IP packets based on a packet’s destination IP address
LLM Explanation: The main functions of a routing protocol are to learn routes from neighboring routers and advertise known routes to neighboring routers. The routes learned from neighbors are then inserted into the routing table. Directly connected routes are not learned via a routing protocol, but rather through the interface configuration on the router itself. Forwarding IP packets based on the destination address is a function of the router's forwarding logic, not the routing protocol.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 16: Routing Protocol Concepts and Configuration', 'Cisco Press: Routing Protocols Companion Guide, Chapter 1: Routing Concepts']

Question Text: When you open a web browser and type in the hostname www.examsdigest.com, your computer does not send an IP packet with a destination IP address www.examsdigest.com; it sends an IP packet to an IP address used by the web server for Examsdigest. TCP/IP needs a way to let a computer find the IP address used by the listed hostname. That method uses the Domain Name System (DNS).
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. When a user enters a hostname like www.examsdigest.com in a web browser, the computer does not directly send an IP packet to that hostname. Instead, it first needs to resolve the hostname to its corresponding IP address. This process is handled by the Domain Name System (DNS). The computer sends a DNS query to a DNS server, which then returns the IP address associated with the hostname. Once the computer has the IP address, it can then send the IP packet to that address to establish communication with the web server.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of WANs and IP Routing', 'https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/dns/what-is-dns/']

Question Text: A __________________ address is an address that enables transmission to every node in a local network.
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Multicast
c. Unicast
d. MAC
LLM Explanation: A broadcast address is used to transmit data to every node on a local network segment. It allows a device to send a single packet that will be received by all devices on that network. Broadcast addresses have all host bits set to binary 1.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition) by Kurose and Ross', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: TCP and ______________ are the two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols.
Choices:
a. UDP
b. HTTP
c. DNS
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is the correct answer. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP are the two most commonly used transport layer protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite. TCP provides reliable, connection-oriented communication, while UDP provides unreliable, connectionless communication. HTTP, DNS, and SMTP are application layer protocols that operate above the transport layer.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition). Pearson.', 'IETF RFC 793: Transmission Control Protocol. https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc793', 'IETF RFC 768: User Datagram Protocol. https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc768']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Frame Check Sequence (FCS) field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet frame provides a method for the receiving Network Interface Card (NIC) to determine if the frame experienced any transmission errors. The FCS is a 32-bit Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC) value calculated by the sending device based on the frame contents. The receiving device recalculates the CRC and compares it with the FCS value in the frame. If they match, the frame is considered error-free; otherwise, the frame is discarded due to transmission errors.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs)', 'IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet']
